replies.bodyText:
I had the logs outside the switch initially, but was seeing a ton of "Orchestrator transitioning from SYNC_VIA_API to SYNC_VIA_API" logs.  I moved them into the switch, so it would only log the 6 transitions that actually matter :)
I've been thinking about log levels and feel like the following makes sense:

Verbose should be used when logging something for every instance of a model
Debug should be used when logging something for every model type
Info should be used for general state changes in the orchestrator or any of the processors, that only result in ~1 instance of the log message

replies.bodyText: This was already there, I just moved it a bit :). I believe the root cause though is that we didn't have a similar check for the ReplaySubject buffer before.  We did check hasThrowable, but I don't think that's quite the same.  So, the solution I've implemented is to just simplify and get rid of the buffer entirely.
replies.author: richardmcclellan

timeline.bodyText:
Before making any of the changes in this PR, I was not able to reproduce this crash if only one subscription is active (just ON_CREATE, for 1 model).  The basic issue causing the crash is due to the following sequence of events:

Going offline closes the socket, which calls AmplifyWebSocketListener::onFailure
onSubscriptionFailure is called for the first subscription
The error is passed to the buffer (buffer.onError())
onPipelineBroken::call (the Action that the Orchestrator calls on error)
Orchestrator::stopApiBlocking is called
SubscriptionProcessor::stopAllSubscriptionActivity is called, which disposes of the TWO disposables in SubscriptionProcessor: the buffer, and the subscriptionObservables.
onSubscriptionFailure is called for the second subscription
At this point, the buffer is already disposed, and the app crashes with: io.reactivex.exceptions.UndeliverableException: The exception could not be delivered to the consumer because it has already canceled/disposed the flow or the exception has nowhere to go to begin with

This PR solves the problem by removing the buffer entirely, and just streaming SubscriptionEvent objects from the subscriptionObservables directly to the Merger.  The SubscriptionProcessor is now only managing  one Disposable (the subscriptionObservable stream) instead of two.   The same crash doesn't occur with the subscriptionObservable stream, because there is an explicit check to see if the stream is disposed before emitting errors on it.  I don't think a similar check was possible with the buffer though, since it was a ReplaySubject, which I don't believe has a way to check if it has been disposed or not.
The one side effect of this change is that SubscriptionEvent are sent to the Merger as they arrive, instead of waiting for all subscriptions to be started.  I don't believe there is any problem with this, but just calling it out.
timeline.author: richardmcclellan

replies.bodyText: This comment is out of date, right?
replies.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Yes, it is out of date.  I put the buffer back, because I believe it is needed to prevent a data inconsistency scenario.      Instead, this PR solves the crash by only using the buffer for SubscriptionEvents, not errors.  Errors are kept out of any RX stream since it may be disposed, and instead sent to a error callback provided by the Orchestrator.

timeline.bodyText:
Previously there was no logic for cleaning up the subscriptions array.  Adding this here ensures that:

the subscription objects are properly removed from subscriptions
the websocket is closed when subscriptions.size() == 0.
timeline.author: richardmcclellan

timeline.bodyText:
For the following use case:

There is no internet connection.
Client attempts to save a mutation.

This change ensures that we fail immediately, instead of waiting 10 seconds for the start_ack.
timeline.author: richardmcclellan

timeline.bodyText:
This was a bug.  We can't just set canceled to true.  We have to actually do the cancellation too.
I've also removed the !canceled.get() guard, because the cancel method itself is already idempotent, and once a subscription is cancelled, it won't throw any additional errors.
timeline.author: richardmcclellan

timeline.bodyText:
This is the most important change in this whole PR.  Instead of passing errors to the emitter, and then to the buffer, all errors are sent directly to an onFailure callback which the Orchestrator passes in to the SubscriptionProcessor on initialization.
Basically, we are no longer sending errors to any stream, since those streams end up getting disposed after receiving an error, which was causing the crash.
timeline.author: richardmcclellan

timeline.bodyText: This change ensures that if there is the device has no network connection, the subscription will fail immediately, instead of failing due to timeout awaiting the start_ack after 10 seconds.
